title-group.article-title: PAYMENT ARREARS IN ROTATING SAVINGS AND CREDIT ASSOCIATIONS: EMPIRICAL ANALYSIS OF CAMEROONIAN ROSCAS

abstract.p: Rotating savings and credit associations (RoSCAs) are well known for their low transactions costs, high recovery rates, and ubiquity. However, the complexity and diversity of RoSCAs is often overlooked in formal modeling and in policy discussions. Using data from the records of 58 RoSCAs operating in urban Cameroon this paper provides evidence of the range of financial contracts available through RoSCAs and of uneven performance among associations. Further data from a survey of RoSCAs participants indicates that individuals develop diversified portfolios by participating in multiple financial institutions. Statistical analysis reveals correlation between institutional features, such as the provision of insurance within the RoSCA, and payment delinquency. While all the RoSCAs surveyed achieve high rates of loan recovery, differences in rates of arrears indicate issues for consideration in the design of formal financial institutions.
